questions.text: Moth eaten bone is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

Option B:

 

MULTIPLE MYELOMA

 

  • Radiographically, multiple myeloma appears as multiple, “punched-out”, sharply demarcated, purely lytic lesions without any surrounding reactive sclerosis.
  • Permeative or moth-eaten appearance of bone appears as multiple endosteal lucent lesions with a poor zone of transition. It is due to bone marrow involvement. 

 

 

  • The lack of reactive bone formation also is shown by the fact that most lesions are negative on bone scan.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteoid osteoma. Plain radiograph may be normal or may show a solid periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. The nidus can be sometimes visible as a well-circumscribed lucent region, occasionally with a central sclerotic dot. However, dense sclerosis may sometimes obscure the nidus. 

 

 

Option C. Eosinophilic granuloma. The radiographic features vary considerably, depending on the site of the lesion. In the skull, a round to oval osteolytic lesion is seen. The lesion have sharp borders, with a punched-out appearance. In the spine, the thoracic vertebrae are involved most often (54%), followed by lumbar (35%) and cervical (1 1%) vertebrae. The body of the vertebra is affected; the posterior elements are usually spared. Fractures of the vertebral bodies may cause marked compression, resulting in the characteristic vertebra plana or silver-coin appearance. The diaphysis is the most common region involved in the long bones.

 

 

Option D. Chodromyxoid fibroma. Plain radiograph may show lobulated or oval eccentric lytic lesion, well-defined sclerotic margin, often expansile, with long axis parallel to long axis of long bone, no periosteal reaction (unless a complicating fracture present), geographic bone destruction, and presence of septations (pseudotrabeculation).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Moth-eaten bone is seen in radiographic image of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: In Synovial sarcoma, gene affected is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SYT-SSX

 

Option A:

 

SYNOVIAL CELL SARCOMA

 

  • Synovial cell sarcoma (previously called ‘synovioma') is an uncommon malignant mesenchymal neoplasm comprising 8-10% of soft tissue sarcomas.
  • The term ‘synovial cell sarcoma' is however a misnomer as synovial cell sarcomas do not arise from synovium.
  • The term was designated because the histological appearance of cells from synovial sarcoma resembles normal synovial tissue.
  • Etiology:
    • Most synovial sarcomas are associated with a characteristic translocation involving chromosome X and chromosome 18 i.e., t(X; 18) giving rise to SYT- SSX fusion genes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. MIC 2. MIC 2 gene is a specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.

 

Option C. RAS. This gene is affected in pancreatic, lung and colorectal cancers.

 

Option D. P53. This gene is affected in breast, colorectal, liver, lung and ovarian cancers.

 

Educational objective:

 

In synovial cell carcinoma, SYT-SSX gene is affected.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in back. Lab investigation shows elevated ESR. X-ray skull shows multiple punched out lytic lesions. Most important Investigation to be done is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum electrophoresis

 

Option D:

 

  • This patient has:
    • Multiple punched out lytic lesions of skull
    • Elevated ESR
    • Back pain
  • Diagnosis is multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is diagnosed by M bands on serum electrophoresis.
  • Punched out lesions of skull are seen both in Eosinophilic granuloma and multiple myeloma.
  • However, bevelled edges (double contour) is characteristic of eosinophilic granuloma due to uneven destruction of the inner and outer table of the skull.
    • Punched out lesions of skull – Multiple myeloma
    • Punched out lesions with bevelled edges – Eosinophilic granuloma

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Serum acid phosphatase. Serum phosphatase levels are lower or normal in multiple myeloma. So, it cannot be used as a sole diagnostic marker for multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. CT head with contrast. The role of radiological imaging in multiple myeloma is essential in the initial staging of the disease, in the detection and characterisation of complications, and in the evaluation of patient's response to treatment.

 

Option C. Whole body scan. Whole-body MRI is the most sensitive technique for detecting bone involvement and assessing painful complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The investigation of choice for the patient with pain in back, elevated ESR, and multiple punched out lytic lesions on skull x-ray is serum electrophoresis, which shows monoclonal gammopathy, confirming the diagnosis as multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the X-ray depicted below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

Option B:

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic.
  • The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.

 

 

  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells).
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.
  • Treatment options:
    • Extended Curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – procedure of choice for most lesions
    • Excision of lower end of ulna, upper end of fibula
    • Excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft – lower end of radius where upper end of fibula is grafted
    • Excision and arthrodesis or prosthetic replacement or Turn-O-Plasty (Bone ends are cut and rotated) – lower end femur and upper end tibia
    • Amputation
    • Malignant recurrent GCT – Radiotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Chondrosarcoma can occur in any location; however, most are located in a proximal location such as the pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Although chondrosarcomas rarely occur in the hand, they are the most common malignant tumor of bone in this location. The radiographic appearance of chondrosarcoma lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of calcification has been described as “punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. Chondrosarcoma has a more aggressive appearance with bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass.

 

 

Option C. Osteogenic sarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Typical radiographic appearances include medullary and cortical bone destruction, permeative or moth-eaten appearance, aggressive periosteal reaction, sunburst appearance, Codman triangle.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Osteoid sarcoma. Osteoid osteoma accounts for 10% of all benign bone tumors. It is neither locally aggressive nor does it have the potential for malignant transformation. This bone tumor frequently affects the long bones of the femur and tibia. It presents with a nidus of vascular osteoid with surrounding sclerotic bone. Osteoid osteomas in long bones are predominantly intracortical. Plain radiograph may be normal or may show a solid periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. The nidus is sometimes visible as a well-circumscribed lucent region, occasionally with a central sclerotic dot. However, dense sclerosis may sometimes obscure the nidus. 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The shown x-ray image is characteristic of osteoclastoma or GCT of the distal end of the radius.

questions.text:
True about Bone metastasis are: 

 

  1. 5% bone metastasis are symptomatic
  2. Higher serum levels of alkaline phosphatase
  3. Most common secondary in female is breast
  4. Prostate produce osteosclerotic lesion
  5. Commonly involves hand and feet bones
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

Option D:

 

  • Most common tumor producing bone metastasis in females is breast carcinoma and in males is prostatic carcinoma.
  • Prostatic carcinoma produces osteoblastic (osteosclerotic) lesions.
  • Osteoblastic lesions are associated with higher serum levels of alkaline phosphatase (reflecting high activity of osteoblasts).
  • Metastases below elbow and knee are rare.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Most of the patients (about 75%) with bone metastasis presents with a common symptom of pain.
  • Patients with solid cancer and bone lesions have a higher mean level of ALP compared with Multiple Myeloma while the lowest levels of ALP can be found in patients with bone metastatic kidney cancer.
  • Breast cancer and prostate cancer are the most common cause of bone metastasis.
  • Lower extremities, pelvis and vertebrae are more commonly involved in bone metastasis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male complains of multiple bone pains. On evaluation, he has high ESR, high Calcium values, lytic lesion in multiple bones, and >20% plasma cells in peripheral smear. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma cell leukemia

 

Option C:

 

  • More than 20% plasma cells in PS – Plasma cell leukemia

 

PLASMA CELL LEUKEMIA

 

  • Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a rare, and aggressive form of multiple myeloma (MM) characterized by plasma cells circulating in the peripheral blood that can be detected on conventional peripheral blood smear examination.
  • PCL can either originate de novo (primary PCL) or as a secondary leukemic transformation of MM (secondary PCL).
  • Primary PCL is more common in younger patients accompanied by hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, extramedullary disease, renal failure, hypercalcemia, thrombocytopenia, increased LDH levels.
  • The del(17p), t(11;14), and t(14;16) are common in primary PCL patients.
  • Chromosome 1 abnormalities are more common in PCL than in MM and are more frequent in secondary PCL than in primary PCL.
  • According to a recent study, TP53 mutations are significantly more common in primary PCL than in MM patients. 
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is common.
  • Most patients present with cytopenia and extramedullary involvement of the liver, spleen, and other organs besides the blood.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma. Diagnosis of MM is made if plasmacytosis (>10%) is present with either  lytic bone lesion, serum or urine M component, progressive increase in M component over time or extramedullary mass lesion development.

 

Option B. Hairy cell leukemia. The hairy cell has characteristic-appearing mononuclear cells which are typically large with circumferential hair-like cytoplasmic projections and a round, well-defined nucleus. The flow cytometry markers positive in hairy cell leukemia include CD11c, CD25, CD103, and CD123, along with typical B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, or CD22. The cyclin-d1 expression is usually present, but it is weak or focal. HCL-V is negative for CD25 and CD123. BRAF-mutation V600E is seen in nearly all cases of classic hairy cell leukemia. 80% patients have cytopenias on presentation. Splenomegaly is a predominant feature. Infectious complications are common, due to both the underlying immunosuppression from cytopenias and myelosuppressive therapy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given history of multiple bone pain, high ESR and calcium levels, with >20% plasma cells and lytic lesions is characteristic of plasma cell leukemia.

questions.text: Which metabolic condition has phosphaturia and osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrosarcoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Vitamin D resistant rickets or osteomalacia can be associated with:
    • Hemangiopericytomas
    • Fibrosarcoma
    • GCT
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Pigmented Villo Nodular synovitis
  • The mediator is phosphatonin – FGF-23
  • It is a reversible condition along with malignancy.

 

FIBROSARCOMA

 

  • Fibrosarcomas are malignant neoplasms composed of fibroblasts with collagen production and a "herringbone" architecture.
  • Depending upon the origin, there are 2 main categories of fibrosarcomas: bone and soft tissue tumors.
  • Fibrosarcomas can be subdivided into 2 types: infantile or congenital fibrosarcomas and adult-type fibrosarcomas.
  • Infantile fibrosarcomas rarely metastasize, while adult-type fibrosarcomas are highly malignant.
  • Fibrosarcomas typically originate from fascia and tendons of soft tissue but can also occur in bones as a primary or secondary tumor within the medullary canal or the periosteum.
  • Prior bone damage, from trauma or radiotherapy, may give rise to fibrosarcomas of the bone.
  • Adult fibrosarcoma is most common in middle-aged and older adults.
  • Males have a slight predominance, most commonly involving the deep soft tissues of the extremities, trunk, head, and neck.
  • The bony fibrosarcoma of the femur and tibia are the most common sites for lesions, followed by the humerus.
  • These pathological lesions are typically metaphyseal in origin.
  • Oncogenic Osteomalacia is a paraneoplastic syndrome of renal phosphate wasting caused by fibrosarcoma. Patients may present with osteopenia and pathologic fractures.
  • The tumor secretes a humoral factor ("phosphatonin") that affects the proximal renal tubules → reduces calcitriol production in the kidney → inhibits phosphate transport → leads to increased renal phosphate excretion, hypophosphatemia and osteomalacia

 

Explanation:

 

Tumor-induced osteomalacia and phosphaturia are not seen in Osteosarcoma (Option B), Undifferentiated sarcoma (Option C), and Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (Option D).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tumour-induced osteomalacia (TIO), is a rare paraneoplasatic syndrome found in >95% of benign tumours that secrete fibroblast growth factor 23 – a phosphaturic circulating hormone.

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma – Onion peel appearance
Secondaries of spine – Winking owl sign

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chondroblastoma – Soap bubble appearance

 

Option B:

 

CLASSICAL RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES

 

 

Note: While marking answers on calcifications choose cartilaginous tumors before osteogenic and amongst cartilaginous prefer malignant more than benign.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteosarcoma – Sunray appearance.

 

 

Option C. Ewing’s sarcoma – Onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option D. Secondaries of spine – Winking owl sign.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chondroblastoma shows chicken wire calcification on biopsy.

questions.text: X-ray proximal femur in a patient with pain in hip is given below. The deformity shown is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

Option B:

 

RADIOGRAPHIC FINDINGS IN FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim the so called ‘Rind sign’.

 


(A) Shepherd crook deformity (B) Rind sign

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Chicken wire calcification is classically seen in the chondroblastoma.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. This is seen in the radiographic image of the spine in hemangioma of the bone, as thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae, giving a jailhouse appearance.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the shepherd crook deformity of the proximal femur, seen in case of fibrous dysplasia of the bone.

questions.text: True about Ameloblastoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystic lesion

 

Option A:

 

AMELOBLASTOMA

 

  • Most common site of ameloblastoma is mandible.
  • Most common site of ameloblastoma of long bones (i.e. adamantinoma) is Tibial diaphysis.
  • Adamantinoma is a slow growing benign locally aggressive tumor with late metastasis.
  • Well demarcated lytic (cystic) or mixed lytic/sclerotic lesion involving the cortex.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rapidly growing. This is false. Ameloblastoma are slow growing tumors.

 

Option C. Malignant disease. This is false. Ameloblastoma are benign tumors.

 

Option D. MC site is tibia. This is false. The most common site is the posterior mandible in the area of the molar teeth. Among the long bones, tibial diaphysis is a common site. In the long bones, this tumor is known as adamantinoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ameloblastoma is a cystic benign tumor that causes cystic degeneration of the bone.

questions.text:
McCune-Albright syndrome features are:

 

  1. High calcium
  2. Presents around puberty
  3. Cysts in long bones
  4. Precocious puberty
  5. High ACTH levels
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

Option A:

 

  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precocious puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots seen in Albright-McCune syndrome have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • It occurs due to gain of function mutations of GNAS (Gs protein) leading to increased cAMP.

 

 

X-ray upper end humerus

 

Educational objective:

 

  • McCune-Albright Syndrome is characterized by a triad of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of the bones (the replacement of the normal bones and marrow by the fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone); precocious puberty (peripheral and due to activation of ovarian or testicular tissue); and café-au-late spots (cutaneous pigmentation).
  • It presents during the time of puberty.
  • The bones presents with cystic lesions with radiographs presenting thinned cortex and intramedullary ground glass appearance.
  • There is increased level of growth hormones.
  • Hyperthyroidism is a feature.

questions.text:
Radio-resistant bone tumor among the following are:

 

  1. Ewing’s Sarcoma
  2. Osteosarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Chondrosarcoma
  5. Lymphoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4

 

Option D:

 

RADIO-RESISTANT BONE TUMOR

 

  • Metastatic renal cell carcinoma
  • Liposarcoma
  • Synovial cell sarcoma
  • Osteosarcoma (most resistant)
  • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma
  • Fibrosarcoma of bone
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Malignant GCT

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma (most radioresistant) and Chondrosarcoma as the radio-resistant tumors.
  • Ewing’s sarcoma (most radio-sensitive), Multiple myeloma, and Lymphoma are radio-sensitive tumors.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true about Ewing sarcoma? 

 

  1. Vascular origin
  2. Ewing’s sarcoma is second most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescent after Osteosarcoma
  3. Metaphysis of long bone is most common site
  4. Fever and weight loss may be present
  5. Surgery is very useful in management
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 4, 5

 

Option D:

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  1. Vascular origin: Incorrect — Ewing sarcoma is a neuroectodermal tumor, not of vascular origin. It arises from primitive neuroectodermal cells (PNET).
  2. Ewing’s sarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents after osteosarcoma: Correct — Osteosarcoma is the first, and Ewing sarcoma is second most common tumor in this age group.
  3. Metaphysis of long bone is the most common site: Incorrect — Ewing sarcoma most commonly affects the diaphysis of long bones (like femur, tibia, humerus) and also flat bones like pelvis.
  4. Fever and weight loss may be present: Correct — Ewing sarcoma can mimic infection with systemic signs like fever, weight loss, and leukocytosis.
  5. Surgery is very useful in management: Correct — Surgery plays a key role along with chemotherapy and radiotherapy for local control and improving outcomes. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ewing’s sarcoma is the 2nd most common primary malignant tumor in children <10 years of age and adolescents after osteosarcoma. 
  • Diaphysis of the long bones is the most common site of origin. 
  • Patients may also present with systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss. 
  • Surgery is a useful treatment option. 
  • Best results are achieved by pre-operative chemotherapy, followed by wide excision or amputation, followed by chemotherapy for 1 year.

questions.text: GCT malignant component is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mononuclear cells

 

Option B:

 

  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells).
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Giant cells. The multinucleated giant cells in the GCT are benign in nature.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The mononuclear stromal cells around the multinucleated giant cells in the GCT are the malignant components of the tumor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with hip pain for last 6 months. Hip X-ray is as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

Option A:

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia.
  • GCT has an egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic.
  • The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.

 

 

  • Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells).
  • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.
  • Giant cell variants (Tumor with giant cells):
    • Brown tumor of hyperparathyroidism
    • Aneurysmal bone cyst (closest) and unicameral bone cyst
    • Non-ossifying fibroma (commonest) and Fibrous dysplasia
    • Osteoblastoma and Osteosarcoma
    • Metastatic carcinoma with giant cells
    • Chondromyxoid fibroma and Chondroblastoma
    • Pigmented villonodular synovitis (mostly occurring in knee)
    • Benign fibrous histiocytoma
    • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma
    • Fibrosarcoma
    • Clear cell chondrosarcoma.
  • Treatment options:
    • Extended Curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – procedure of choice for most lesions
    • Excision of lower end of ulna, upper end of fibula
    • Excision and replacement by vascularized bone graft – lower end of radius where upper end of fibula is grafted
    • Excision and arthrodesis or prosthetic replacement or Turn-O-Plasty (Bone ends are cut and rotated) – lower end femur and upper end tibia
    • Amputation
    • Malignant recurrent GCT – Radiotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Simple bone cyst. Unicameral bone cysts are most common in the proximal humerus and femur. The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity. Unicameral bone cysts are often asymptomatic, unless a pathological fracture has occurred. Plain radiographs reveal a centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline. Occasionally (20%), a thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature. This “fallen fragment” sign is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst, bone fragment, may also hinge around and move with fluid called as trap door sign.

 

 

Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Option C. Adamantinoma. Adamantinomas are rare, low-grade malignant bone tumors that predominately affect the diaphyses and metaphyses of the tibia. The tumor is called adamantinoma due to its histological similarity to ameloblastoma, often found in the mandible. Histopathologically, adamantinoma displays biphasic patterns consisting of epithelial cells and osteofibrous components. On x-ray, it appears as a well-circumscribed, cortical tumor with a multilobulated, osteolytic pattern. Intralesional opacities, septation, and peripheral sclerosis may also be seen. These multifocal radiolucencies, surrounded by ring-shaped densities, produce the characteristic ''soap-bubble'' appearance. The lesion is typically confined within the intracortical region and extends longitudinally along the bone. However, in some cases, it can result in cortical destruction and invade the medullary cavity or adjacent periosteum and soft tissues. In such cases, a lamellar or solid periosteal reaction is typically associated with the lesion.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. In reality, Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given x-ray in the question shows eccentric giant cell tumor of the proximal femur.

questions.text:
Which among the following is/are metaphyseal tumor?

 

  1. Chondrosarcoma
  2. Enchondroma
  3. Giant cell tumor
  4. Ameloblastoma
  5. Osteosarcoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

 

Option D:

 

 

Note: Osteomyelitis also starts in metaphysis.

 

 

Sites of bone tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, Chondrosarcoma, Enchondroma and Osteosarcoma are the tumors that affect the metaphyseal region of the bone whereas Giant cell tumor affects the epiphyseal region of the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of geographic lesion of bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Geographic bone lesion implies a lesion with a sharply-defined border.
  • This can also be described as a narrow zone of transition between pathologic and normal bone.
  • A geographic appearance implies a benign or less aggressive tumour.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrous dysplasia. It is a type 1A geographic lesion.

 

Option B. Brodie’s abscess. It is also a geographic lytic lesion.

 

Option C. Giant cell tumor. It is a type 1B geographic lesion.
 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ewing’s sarcoma is a type of a permeative lytic lesion which is poorly demarcated and numerous.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood tumors most frequently metastasizes to the bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuroblastoma

 

  • Neuroblastoma is a cancer that arises from immature nerve cells (neuroblasts) typically found in the adrenal glands, abdomen, chest, neck, or pelvis. 
  • It is one of the most common solid extracranial tumors in children.
  • Neuroblastoma is known for its aggressive nature and high propensity to metastasize early in its course.
  • The bone and bone marrow are exceptionally common sites for neuroblastoma metastasis. 
  • In many cases, bone or bone marrow involvement is present at the time of initial diagnosis, indicating advanced-stage disease. 
  • This predilection for bone metastasis is a key characteristic of neuroblastoma that differentiates it from other childhood cancers in terms of metastatic patterns. 
  • These metastases can cause bone pain, pathological fractures, and cytopenias due to bone marrow involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ganglioneuroma. Ganglioneuroma is an uncommon neurogenic tumor arising from sympathetic ganglia. Most of the patients are older than 10 years. The posterior mediastinum is the main localization followed by the retroperitoneum and cervical region. This is a benign tumor. Benign tumors do not metastasize.

 

Option C. Wilm’s tumor. Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common renal cancer in the pediatric age group. Wilms tumor is typically found in children younger than five years of age. The most common site of metastatic spread of Wilms tumor is the lungs (most frequent) and the liver. Bone metastases from Wilms' tumor are relatively rare.

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. This is a primary bone tumor (or sometimes soft tissue tumor that invades bone). This means it originates in the bone itself. Therefore, it doesn't "metastasize to the bone" from a distant primary site in the same way. Ewing’s sarcoma mostly happens in children and young adults, although it can happen at any age. It most often begins in the leg bones and pelvis, but it can happen in any bone. It can involve the muscle and the soft tissues around the tumor as well. The cells can also metastasize to other areas of the body, including the bone marrow, lungs, kidneys, heart, adrenal glands and other soft tissues. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor in children that metastasize to the bone frequently. 
  • It is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor, classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. 
  • Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. 
  • Neuroblastoma may metastasize to lymph nodes, bone marrow, liver, skin and bones. 
  • Bone to bone metastasis is seen in Osteosarcoma, Neuroblastoma, Ewing's Sarcoma [B O N E] (Maximum incidence of a particular tumor type).

choices.text: The femur and tibia are the commonest bones involved
Radiologically appears as a radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense bone
It is a benign bone tumor, presents with severe pain that is typically relieved by aspirin

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding osteoid osteoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • MC in Femur Diaphysis
  • It is commonest benign true bone tumor, exceeded in incidence only by osteochondroma and non-ossifying fibroma.
  • The typical patient with an osteoid osteoma has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications.
  • When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur.
  • Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen.
  • The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis.
  • Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed).
  • CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
  • D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island.
  • Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma.

 

 

  • Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

Note: The literature now supports that osteoid osteoma is showing higher incidence in metaphysis. Even then the clinical scenario given is such that it is mentioned as diaphyseal.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that presents with severe pain, which is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications.
  • The femur and tibia are the most commonly involved bones.
  • Radiologically, it appears as a radiolucent lesion surrounded by dense bone.

questions.text: Development of Chondrosarcomas is related with:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A and C

 

Option D)

 

  • Chondromas or Chondroasarcomas are benign lesions of hyaline cartilage. 
  • They are the most common tumor of the small bones of the hands and feet. 
  • They usually arise in the medullary canal, where they are referred to as “enchondromas”. 
  • Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a preexisting benign cartilage lesion. 
  • They occur most frequently in the setting of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses.
  • Maffucci’s syndrome is a rare non-hereditary disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas (benign cartilage tumors), subcutaneous hemangiomas (tumors of blood vessels) and phleboliths.
  • Individuals with Maffucci syndrome have a significantly increased risk of developing chondrosarcomas.

 

 

Enchondroma

 

 

Mafucci syndrome: (A) Hemangiomas (B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • When multiple enchondromas are present, the condition is called as Ollier disease. 
  • Ollier disease is characterized by an asymmetric distribution of cartilage lesions. 
  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in <2% in solitary cases, 30% in Ollier’s disease and 100% in Maffucci’s syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Felty syndrome. Felty syndrome is an uncommon extra-articular manifestation of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis (RA) characterized by RA, neutropenia (ANC<1500 mm3), and splenomegaly. HLA-DR4 has been noted to be present in >90% of Felty syndrome cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Maffucci syndrome and Ollier's disease are well-established conditions that predispose individuals to the development of chondrosarcomas due to the presence of multiple enchondromas.

questions.text: X-ray of Tibia of an adolescent boy is shown. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chondromyxoid fibroma

 

Option A:

 

CHONDROMYXOID FIBROMA

 

  • Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin.
  • Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly it occur in patients 10-30 years old.
  • Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location.
  • In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent.
  • Plain radiograph shows lobulated or oval eccentric lytic lesion with well-defined sclerotic margin, often expansile, with long axis parallel to long axis of long bone.
  • There is no periosteal reaction, unless a complicating fracture is present.
  • The geographic bone destruction is almost 100%.
  • There is a presence of septations (pseudotrabeculation) in about 60% cases.
  • Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Radiographically, the periosteal reaction may be seen in the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. The codman’s triangle is formed by the periosteal lifting. There is also new bone formation in the soft tissues along with permeative pattern of bone destruction.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option C. Bone cyst with fracture. Benign bone cysts generally do not cause pain, but if they are large enough, they can weaken the bone and cause it to fracture. This type of fracture is called a pathologic fracture. A classic radiographic finding is the fallen fragment sign which occurs when a piece of cortex breaks off after a fracture, and sinks to the gravity-dependent portion of the lesion.

 

 

Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

 

Option D. Fibrosis cystica. Cystic fibrosis (CF), also called mucoviscidosis, is an autosomal recessive genetic disease that affects the exocrine function of the lungs, liver, pancreas, small bowel, sweat glands, and the male genital system. The musculoskeletal manifestations of cystic fibrosis are uncommon. Musculoskeletal manifestations include low bone mineral density, short stature, kyphosis, cystic fibrosis arthropathy (~5%), hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (~5%), finger clubbing.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a chondromyxoid fibroma of the tibia with lobulated or oval eccentric lytic lesion with well-defined sclerotic margin.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with chronic knee pain for 2 years. Knee X-ray is shown below. Probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Option B:

 

  • In the given image, Codman’s Triangle is shown, which is seen in the osteosarcoma.

 

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance.
  • It occurs when the bone lesion grows aggressively that it lifts the periosteum off the bone and do not allow the periosteum to lay down new bone.
  • The periosteal reaction is interrupted type.
  • The central aspect of the lesion does not have any overlying ossification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic osteomyelitis. Homogeneous osteosclerosis and/or sequestrum formation is characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis on radiograph.

 

 

Option C. Rickets. There is growth plate widening and abnormal configuration of the metaphysis, seen as fraying (indistinct margins of the metaphysis); splaying (widening of metaphyseal ends); cupping (concavity of metaphysis) and pseudofracture on the compression side of bone known as Looser's zone.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Radiological Features of Hyperparathyroidism are subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis. There is loss of lamina dura of tooth socket surrounding teeth, generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae. There is also the presence of brown tumors and salt pepper appearance of the skull.

 

 

Brown tumors

 

 

Salt pepper appearance of the skull

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows the formation of codman’s triangle which is seen in the cases of osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Peak incidence of osteosarcoma occurs at:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2nd decade

 

Option A:

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life.
  • All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus.
  • Secondary osteosarcomas occur at the site of another disease process.
  • They rarely occur in young patients, but constitute almost half of the osteosarcomas in patients older than age 50 years.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Primary osteosarcoma is primarily seen in the 2nd decade of life whereas the secondary osteosarcoma is seen in patients >50 years of age.

questions.text: 22 year old male present with bony mass in the metaphyseal region of right. knee with typical sun ray appearance and CT Scan of the chest reveals osteoblastic metastases. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

Option A:

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The periosteal reaction in the osteosarcoma may show as the sunray appearance on the radiograph.

 

 

Sunray appearance

 

  • CT scan of the chest are done to search for pulmonary metastasis.
  • Lungs are the most common sites for metastases.
  • The most important prognostic factor at the time of diagnosis is the extent of the disease (staging).
  • Approximately 15% of patients with osteosarcoma have detectable pulmonary metastases at the time of diagnosis.
  • As a group, these patients continue to have a poor prognosis with less than 20% long-term survival.
  • Patients with non-pulmonary metastases (e.g., bone metastases) have an even worse prognosis.
  • Patients with “skip” metastases (i.e., a metastasis within the same bone as the primary tumor or across the joint from the primary tumor) have the same poor prognosis as patients with distant metastases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chondrosarcoma.  The radiographic appearance of chondrosarcoma shows a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of calcification is described as “punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. There is bone destruction, cortical erosions, and periosteal reaction. Chondrosarcoma is a highly malignant tumor with the potent capacity to cause local invasion and distant metastasis, preferentially in the lungs.

 

 

Option C. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Lung is the most common site of metastases followed by the bone.

 

 

Option D. Osteochondroma. An osteochondroma can be either sessile or pedunculated and is seen in the metaphyseal region typically projecting away from the epiphysis. There is associated broadening of the metaphysis from which it arises. The cartilage cap can be thin and difficult to identify, or thick with rings and arcs calcification and irregular subchondral bone. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given characteristics of bony mass in metaphysis of knee with sunray appearance and osteoblastic metastases in chest are seen in the osteosarcoma of the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following malignant tumors is radio-resistant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteosarcoma

 

Option C:

 

Radio-Resistant Bone Tumor

 

  • Metastatic renal cell carcinoma
  • Liposarcoma
  • Synovial cell sarcoma
  • Osteosarcoma (most resistant)
  • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma
  • Fibrosarcoma of bone
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrosarcoma
  • Malignant GCT

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. It is highly radio-sensitive tumor.

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma. It is also a radio-sensitive tumor.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma. It is also a radio-sensitive tumor.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Among the given options, osteosarcoma is a highly radio-resistant tumor. Thus, it is ideally treated with chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: An 8-year-male child presents with progressive swelling of upper end tibia which is irregular with local temperature raised, variable consistency and ill-defined margins. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteogenic sarcoma

 

Option C:

 

  • The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing’s sarcoma and osteosarcoma:
    • History of trivial trauma
    • Progressive swelling
    • Raised local temperature
    • Variable consistency
    • Ill-defined margins
  • However, swelling is around the knee joint at upper end of tibia, which favours the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion).
  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Giant cell tumor. This is commonly seen in the epiphyseal region of the long bones. The lesion is solitary. The swelling is associated with more extensive lesions and a soft tissue mass or bump is occasional.

 

Option B. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing’s sarcoma presents with local rise of temperature, progressive swelling with variable consistency and ill-defined margins but it is seen in the diaphyseal region of the long bones.

 

Option D. Secondary metastasis. Spine and pelvis are the most common sites of secondary metastasis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given clinical features are seen in both osteosarcoma and Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • The only differentiating point is the involvement of the upper end of the tibia i.e., the metaphysis, which is involved in the osteosarcoma and not ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: All of the following investigations are needed for the diagnosis of osteosarcoma, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bone marrow biopsy

 

Option B:

 

  • A biopsy of the lesion (not bone marrow biopsy) should always be carried out before commencing treatment.
  • Bone scan, MRI and CT chest are used.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI of femur. MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.

 

Option C. Bone scan. A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases.

 

Option D. CT chest. CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • All the given investigations are done in a case of osteosarcoma except for the bone marrow biopsy.
  • Instead, biopsy of the lesion if done before starting the treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumor present with secondaries in lung with pneumothorax:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteosarcoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Both osteogenic sarcoma and Ewing's sarcoma may have metastasis to lung.
  • However, it is much more common in osteogenic sarcoma and about 10% of patients have pulmonary metastasis by the time they are first seen.
  • Incidence of pneumothorax is higher in osteosarcoma metastasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ewing’s sarcoma. This tumor also metastasize to lung but osteosarcoma metastasis is more common.

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma. It rarely metastasize to lung.

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. This tumor also metastasize to lung but osteosarcoma metastasis is more common.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma is the most common tumor that metastasize to the lungs with increased incidence of pneumothorax.

questions.text: Characteristic translocation seen in Ewing’s sarcoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) t (11;22)

 

Option B:

 

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22.), differing only in their degree of neural differentiation.
  • Ewing’s sarcoma is poorly differentiated whereas PNET exhibits definite neural differentiation (N myc positive).
  • The t(11; 22) (q24; q12) is the most common translocation diagnostic of Ewing sarcoma and is present in greater than 90% of cases.
  • Other diagnostic translocations includes t(21; 22) (q22; q12), t(7; 22) (p22; q12), trisomy 8 and trisomy 12.
  • MIC2(CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumors and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. t(2;8). This is seen in Burkitt’s lymphoma.

 

Option C. t(x;18). This is seen in synovial sarcoma.

 

Option D. t(14;18). This is seen in follicular lymphoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: In 1st decade of life, the most common bone tumor is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ewing's sarcoma

 

Option A:

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age.
  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. This is commonly seen in 2nd decade of life.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma.  ts incidence peaks in 5th-7th decade of life.

 

Option D. Metastasis. It occurs in patients >40 years of age.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ewing’s sarcoma is common in 1st decade of life, in children younger than 10 years of age.

questions.text: PAS positive cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ewing's sarcoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Ewing sarcomas usually are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) positive (owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. About 27% of osteosarcomas have PAS positive cells. 

 

Option C. Chondrosarcoma. About 92% of chondrosarcomas have PAS positive cells.

 

Option D. Multiple myeloma. Multiple myelomas have PAS negative cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • All ewing sarcomas have PAS positive cells among the given options.

questions.text: Mic 2 positive cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ewing's sarcoma

 

Option A:

 

  • Mic 2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumors and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y.
  • In addition, Ewing sarcomas usually are periodic acid–Schiff positive (owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma, Option C. Chondrosarcoma, and Option D. Multiple myeloma are negative for MIC 2 cells. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • MIC2 is a specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: CD 99 is marker of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing's sarcoma

 

Option B:

 

  • Mic 2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumors and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y.
  • In addition, Ewing sarcomas usually are periodic acid–Schiff positive (owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. CD 34 is the most consistent marker for DFSP.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. RBM 15 and YTHDC1 are the specific markers for osteosarcoma.

 

Option D. Metastasis. Bone metastases tumor biomarkers include bone specific alkaline phosphatase (BALP), tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRACP), tumor necrosis factor (TNF), carbohydrate antigen 15-3 (CA15-3).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • CD 99 is the specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with h/o trauma 2 months back now presents with fever and acute pain over thigh. On X-ray, femoral shaft shows lesions with multiple laminated periosteal reaction. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI

 

Option D:

 

Information in this question are:

 

  • 1st Decade
  • Diaphyseal lesion with onion peel reaction goes towards Ewing’s sarcoma.
  • Next best investigation is MRI for soft tissue involvement, marrow involvement and micro metastasis.
  • Overall, the best investigation is Biopsy to confirm the diagnosis but MRI is done before the biopsy, to localize the best site for biopsy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CRP measurement. In Ewing's sarcoma cases, CRP pre-treatment value >0.5 mg/dL is considered as a sensitive prognostic risk factor indication for distant metastasis and poor prognosis.

 

Option B. Core biopsy. Core biopsy methods are preferable to provide a histological diagnosis of the tumor cell. In some cases, repeated core biopsy attempts may fail to provide a definite result.

 

Option C. Tc99 MDP scan. When Ewing Sarcoma is lytic, MDP bone scan does not add to staging performed by FDG PET/CT; thus, MDP bone scanning may be omitted. However, when Ewing Sarcoma is sclerotic, MDP bone scan may detect osseous metastases not detected by FDG PET/CT.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • MRI is the investigation of choice in ewing’s sarcoma before biopsy is performed.

questions.text: Commonest site of occurrence of chordoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sacrum

 

Option A:

 

  • Chordoma is a rare malignant neoplasm that arises from notochord remnants.
  • Chordoma is the second most common primary malignancy in the spine (behind myeloma) and is the most common primary malignancy of the sacrum.
  • Greater than 50% of chordomas arise in the sacrococcygeal area, and more than 30% arise at the base of the skull. The remainder are dispersed throughout the rest of the spine.

 

 

Chordoma (Sacrum) & Physaliferous cells (Cells with small nuclei and vacuoles in cytoplasm)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Femur. Metaphysis of the femur is most commonly involved in osteosarcoma.

 

Option C. Ribs. Enchondroma is the most comon benign rib lesion after fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Proximal tibia. It is also involved in osteosarcoma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sacrum is most commonly involved in the chordoma.

questions.text: Which of the following tumor is associated with hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chondrosarcoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases.
  • Hyperglycemia occurs as a paraneoplastic syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

There is no association of the tumor with hyperglycemia seen in cases of ewing’s sarcoma (option A), osteosarcoma (option B) and multiple myeloma (option D).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chondrosarcoma can cause hyperglycemia in around 85% cases.

choices.text: Small bones of the hand

questions.text: Metastases is least common in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Small bones of the hand

 

Option D:

 

  • The commonest site for bone metastases are the VERTEBRAE.
  • Extremities distal to elbow and knee are least commonly involved sites.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Skull, pelvis and vertebrae are involved commonly in bone metastasis while the distal extremity bones are least commonly involved.
